story.headline: The Sudd: One of the World's Largest Natural Methane Sources
story.summary: The Sudd is one of the largest tropical wetlands on Earth, spanning over 30,000 km² in South Sudan. As organic matter decomposes in its waterlogged soils, it releases significant quantities of methane — a natural but climate-relevant process.
story.climateImpact: Natural wetland methane emissions from the Sudd contribute to the global methane budget. As temperatures rise, warmer conditions could accelerate microbial decomposition and increase emissions further.
causeEffect: Microbial activity releases methane from organic matter
Changing hydrology from upstream dams alters wetland extent
Political instability limits research and monitoring
story.scaleContext: Global wetlands are the single largest natural source of methane, contributing approximately 150-220 Mt CH₄/year. The Sudd is estimated to contribute 3-7 Mt/year of this total.
story.outlook: Climate-driven changes in rainfall and temperature could either expand or contract the Sudd, with uncertain implications for future methane emissions.
